ALLEGATION:
Incident One: On 1/31/21 Staff 1 left Youth A and B in a vehicle for about 15
minutes. The vehicle was not running, and it was cold out.
Incident Two: In December 2021 Staff 2 dragged Youth C from the couch to the floor
by the arm, then across the floor and halfway down the stairs. Youth C was picked
up by Staff 2 with one arm around his chest.
INVESTIGATION:
Incident One:
On 1/14/2022 it was reported to DCWL that a staff person (Staff 1) left two children
unattended in a vehicle, without heat for approximately 15 minutes. This reportedly
occurred on 1/13/2022. The source further stated the temperature was 32 degrees
that day and the children were not wearing coats. Staff 1 left the children in the car
to assist Staff 2 with a child that was kicking the seat of another car. The source
stated this information was also reported to DHHS and Law Enforcement.
2

Chief Administrator
On 1/14/22 the agency Chief Administrator (CA) was contacted and informed of the
investigation. The CA reported she was aware of the alleged incident.
On 1/18/22 interviews were completed on-site. The Chief Administrator was present
during staff interviews. After the interviews concluded, the CA reported the agency
was in the process of reviewing the information and determining a course of action.
In the meantime, the agency took the following steps:
 Staff 1 documented the incident in an incident report.
 Staff did a well-child check with both children over the weekend after the
alleged incident.
 Staff 1 was interviewed regarding the incident by the program manager.
The CA reported this case has been challenging as one of the parents can make
visits difficult at times. At the end of visits at the parent’s home, the kids will get
upset and not want to leave. The parent will yell at the agency staff that it is their
fault. Sometimes the kids will hit and kick at the workers in an attempt to prevent
leaving. The parent will encourage the kids to try to get away from staff. The parent
also refuses to help staff transition the children at the end of the visit.
Staff 1
On 1/18/22 Staff 1 was interviewed at the agency. Staff 1 stated she was aware of
the allegations, as the parent made it known they would make a report. Staff 1
reported that visits with the parent are always challenging as one of the children has
issues with the transition when it is time to leave the visit. On 1/13/22 Staff 1 was
waiting with Youth A (age 2) after a visit. Youth A was crying because the parent
would not walk out to the car with them. Staff 1 was able to convince Youth A to go
to the car for a snack the parent provided. Staff 1 put Youth A and Youth B (age 3) in
her car. Both youth had their coats on and were buckled in their seats. Staff 1 got in
the car, started it, then noticed the parent was standing at the window yelling, and
recording the worker with her phone. The parent was yelling at Staff 1 that she was
“trafficking children”. Staff 1 stated this claim is something the parent frequently
states.
Also occurring at this time, Youth C (age 6) was getting into Staff 2’s car. Staff 2
requested assistance, as Youth C was kicking the door, causing it to hit the adjacent
car. Staff 1 took the keys out of her car and walked over to assist Staff 2. Staff 2 was
in the parking spot next to Staff 1. Staff 2 was blocking the car door from hitting the
next car. Staff 1 returned to her car to ask Youth A and B if they were ok. Youth B
stated he was scared. Staff 1 reassured him and put a movie on to keep the two
children distracted from their sibling’s behavior. Staff 1 stated she put the key back
in the car to power the movie, but the car was not started. Staff 1 reported that she
tried to help Staff 2 deescalate Youth C by talking with him. Staff 1 was standing
between her car and Staff 1’s car, with the door open, so she could speak with
Youth C. Staff 1 asked if Youth C wanted to speak with his parent. However, the
3

parent had returned to her apartment. Staff 1 called the parent, but the parent yelled
out the window that she would not answer the phone, stating she needed the phone
to call and report the worker. Staff 1 asked Youth C if he wanted to speak with his
grandmother. Youth C agreed and calmed down while speaking to his grandmother.
The incident lasted about 10-15 minutes. Staff 1 reported she was standing next to
her car and checked on Youth A and B approximately 2-3 times. Both children
seemed comfortable watching a movie. Staff 1 stated the kids never reported being
cold or uncomfortable.
Staff 2
Staff 2 was interviewed regarding the incident on 1/13/22 with a follow-up phone call
on 2/16/22. Staff 2’s account matched that of Staff 1. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 was
standing in-between the cars, talking with Youth C for 5-10 minutes. Youth A and B
were in Staff 1’s car at the time. Staff 1 never left her car unattended.
Documents reviewed
Staff 1’s Human Resources file was reviewed. Staff 1 did not have any prior
disciplinary action or concerns documented. Staff 1 had completed required training,
including de-escalation training within the past year.
An incident report dated 1/13/22 was reviewed and found to reflect the information
provided by Staff 1 during the 1/18/22 interview.
A review of National Weather Service records found the temperature at the parent’s
apartment on 1/13/22 was 37 degrees. With or without coats on, and sitting in a car,
the children were not at risk of hypothermia during the 10-15 minute incident, per the
National Weather Service Hypothermia Chart.
Incident Two
On 1/14/22 it was reported to DCWL that around December 2021, Youth A was
dragged off of a couch and onto the floor by Staff 2, during visitation with the child’s
parent. Staff 2 then dragged the child halfway down the stairs. Staff 2 then picked up
Youth C with one hand around his chest/torso and carried him down the stairs and
out of the apartment complex. It was unknown if Youth C was injured. No witnesses
were identified.
Chief Administrator
On 1/14/22 phone contact occurred with the CA to initiate the investigation. On
1/18/22 face to face contact occurred with the CA, as she was present for staff
interviews. In addition, a pre-exit call occurred on 2/16/22.
The CA reported the agency understood the serious nature of the complaint and
completed the following steps to address the situation:
 A review of visits was completed and the agency determined the incident to
have occurred on 11/4/21, not December 2021. An incident report was
provided to DCWL.
4

 On 11/11/21 after an initial report that Staff 2 picked up a child during a visit,
Staff 2 met with administration and received additional de-escalation training.
 Staff 2 was removed from assisting with Youth C’s visits, pending this
investigation.
 Staff 1 completed a well child check with Youth C after receiving the
allegation.
 Staff 2 discussed the situation with their supervisor and Human Resources.
 Staff 2 reviewed the video with her supervisor and discussed points in which
she could have reacted differently. Staff 2 recognized the mistakes she made
and was receptive to education in those areas.
 A behavioral health specialist from the agency began attending visits for this
family and helping establish routines to make transitions easier. Coaching
about cues, routines, and proactive actions was utilized.
 Additional training and supervision are planned for Staff 2, including further
de-escalation training, visit coaching, and crisis intervention training. This
information will be outlined in a Corrective Action Plan for DCWL.
Staff 2
On 1/18/22 an interview was completed with Staff 2 at the agency. Staff 2 reported
being a visitation specialist/case aid for one year. Staff 2 was informed of the
allegation and reported she believed the complaint stemmed from a visit on 11/4/21.
Staff 2 denied pulling Youth C off the couch or dragging him anywhere. Staff 2
reported she was supervising a visit with Staff 1 at the parental home of Youth C.
After the family ate dinner, Youth C became upset about not being able to use his
tablet. While in the living room, Youth C’s behavior escalated. The behavior
continued for the duration of the visit. As they neared the end of the visit, Youth C
began hitting, kicking, throwing objects, and spitting. The parent tried ignoring the
behavior, then held Youth C for a few minutes, but he did not calm down. Staff 2
stated she gave some verbal cues to Youth C, such as “let’s get shoes on”, to let
him know it was almost time to go. Youth C ignored Staff 2. Staff 1 was trying to
assist with Youth C, but she was also attempting to get Youth A and Youth B ready
to go. Staff 2 ran out to the car to put Youth C’s belongings in it. When Staff 2 came
back in Staff 1 was ready to go with Youth A and B. Youth C was covered in a
blanket, sitting on the couch. Staff 2 removed the blanket, took Youth C’s hand, and
said let’s go. Youth C then slid off the couch on to the floor. Staff 1 stated he slid on
his own, as she did not pull him. Staff 2 continued trying to talk with Youth C and
encouraged him to get up to leave. Staff 2 stated that she waited for a few minutes,
but Youth C was not making any effort to leave. Staff 2 then “scooped him up and
carried him out”. The parent was already outside of the apartment at that time, in
the hallway, yelling at Staff 1. The parent saw Staff 2 carrying Youth C into the
hallway. The parent asked Staff 2 to put him down, stating, “you’re hurting him”.
Staff 2 set Youth C down. Youth C began grabbing the spindles of the staircase,
refusing to leave. Staff 1 asked Youth C if he wanted to talk to his grandmother
when they got in the car. This suggestion upset the parent. Staff 1 then began
moving outside to get Youth A and B loaded into her car. During this time, other
people were attempting to use the stairs. Staff 2 stated she thought about trying to
5

take Youth C’s hands off the spindles to keep him from blocking the stairs. However,
the parent was already upset and making allegations. Therefore, Staff 2 decided she
did not want to touch Youth C. A few moments later, Youth C let go of the spindles.
Staff 2 picked up Youth C and took him the rest of the way down the stairs and out
to the car. Youth C was cooperating once they were outside. Youth C was helpful in
putting his socks, shoes, and coat on in the car. Youth C put on his seatbelt without
further incident. Youth C did not make any complaints about being hurt. Staff 2
clarified that when she picked up Youth C, she was behind him and put her arm
around the front of his chest/waist. Staff 1 was at the bottom of the stairs, exiting
with the other children at that time.
Video reviewed
A three-part video of the 11/4/21 incident was reviewed and found the following:
 Youth C was wrapped in a blanket sitting on the couch. The parent told Youth
C he had to leave. Youth C would not let go of the blanket as Staff 2 tried to
move it. Staff 2 picked the blanket up, with Youth C still holding on, and set
the blanket and child on the floor. Staff 2 then removed the blanket from
Youth C’s hands. Staff 2 attempted to stand Youth C up, but he went limp and
sat on the floor. After the second attempt, Staff 2 picked up Youth C with one
arm across his shoulder and around his chest and began carrying him out of
the apartment. When they reached the hallway, the parent asked Staff 2 not
to hold Youth C that way, because Staff 2 was hurting him. Staff 2 set Youth
C on the floor at the top of the steps.
 Staff 2 attempted to pick Youth C up from the front. But Youth C grabbed the
railing. Staff 2 attempted to remove his hands from the railing. Then sat Youth
C on the step and tried to get him to go down the stairs. Youth C began going
back up the stairs, with Staff 2 holding his hands. Staff 2 told Youth C she
was sorry, but they had to go. Youth C continued to struggle to release his
hands from Staff 2.
 Staff 2 let go of Youth C’s hands and he grabbed the railing again. Staff 2
pulled Youth C’s hand from the railing and picked him up from behind, with
her arms around his torso. Another resident of the building then excused
himself past them and up the stairs. Youth C then grabbed the railing again.
The parent stated she was no longer going to help, due to a prior incident
where she was upset with staff. The parent told staff they need to figure it out.
Youth C continued to hold the railing. The parent said, “I’m sorry (Youth C), I
can’t help you”. The parent told Youth C it was Staff 1’s fault he had to go.
Staff 2 removed his hands from the railing again and Youth C sat on the step.
Staff 1 asked Youth C if he wanted to talk to his grandma. The parent
objected to Youth C speaking with his grandma because the parent felt the
staff should handle the situation on their own. Staff 2 then picked up Youth C
in a cradle hold and walked out the door while he continued to struggle.
Documents reviewed
 Staff 2’s Human Resources file was reviewed. Staff 2 received de-escalation
training on 8/17/21 and 11/11/21.
6

 Incident Report dated 11/4/21: The incident report was consistent with the
information provided by Staff 2 during the interview on 1/18/22. After this
incident occurred, Staff 2 was coached by her supervisor about agency
expectations. Staff 2 reviewed de-escalation and safety technique training on
11/11/21. On 11/15/21 Staff 2 met with the supervisor again to discuss tools
she learned from the training and how she could have used them in the
11/4/21 situation. Staff 2 was receptive to learning how to better handle this
situation. Staff 2 was also encouraged by her supervisor to reach out for
assistance when needed, so they may work together to develop a plan.
 Incident report 1/25/21: A child reported to Staff 2 that she was hit by her
parent. Staff 2 reported the information to her supervisor. The supervisor
coached Staff 2 that she needed to report the information directly to DHHS.
Additional mandated reporter training was completed by Staff 2 in January
and August 2021.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12206 Staff qualifications
(1) An agency shall require a staff member who has
ongoing contact with children or parents to be a person
who has the ability, experience, education, and training to
perform the duties assigned.
ANALYSIS: No violation was found as there was not evidence to indicate
Staff 1 acted in an unsafe manner during incident one.
A violation was found for incident two due to Staff 2 using
physical management with Youth C on several occasions during
the 11/4/21 visitation. Staff 2 was observed on video to move
the child from the couch to the floor, pull the youth’s hands from
a railing several times, hold the youth’s hands to prevent him
from going upstairs, and picked the youth up in an effort to
relocate him on three occasions. Physical management is not to
be used by CPA staff in this manner. Staff are not trained in
physical management.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable Corrective Action Plan, I recommend no change in
the license status.
